Explore whether deploying such a system on large-platform healthcare infrastructures is practical through more conversations on the challenges this may pose. In30 Zheng et al. present another approach to privacy-preserving image recognition in remote sensing which makes use of limited visual cryptography. It aims to achieve better privacy protection for sensitive remote sensing data while facilitating accurate image recognition tasks. Yet, the only restriction this approach may face is with the large-scale remote sensing images and real-time requirements. This is particularly so since they do not always imply greater suitability and efficiency of the proposed method to manage broad and versatile remote sensing image datasets. Datta et al.,32 present a blockchain-enabled smart contract model that combines consumer electronics and mobile edge computing to protect healthcare transactions. The model proposed in this paper combines blockchain technologies and smart contracts to strengthen security and privacy for healthcare transactions, along with consumer electronics and mobile edge computing for data processing and management. However, one of the limitations of this work can be the intricate nature and interoperability problems related to the introduction of wide-ranging consumer electronics, mobile edge computing, and blockchain technologies into the healthcare domain. To achieve the seamless integration and functionality of the proposed model in real-world healthcare environments, further research and development efforts may be needed. In the proposed scheme, bilinear mapping is employed as a fundamental component for the implementation of attribute-based encryption (ABE). This choice is motivated by the unique properties and advantages that bilinear mappings offer, particularly in the context of secure and efficient access control mechanisms for electronic medical records (EMRs). We denote both \(G_{0}\) and \(G_{1}\) as cyclic multiplicative groups composed of large prime numbers \(\rho\). Let \(\rho\) be an element of R and \({\mathscr {Q}}\) be the starting point for these groups, containing an element that maps to \(G_{T}\), the same class of cyclic multiplicative groups, represented by 1. The bilinear mapping \({\hat{e}}\) is defined as \({\hat{e}}: G_{1} \times G_{2} \rightarrow G_{T}\). \({\hat{e}}\) is considered a bilinear map if it satisfies the following criteria18,36: Bilinearity: For any elements \(a, b \in {\mathscr {Z}}^*_{\rho }\), and \(\forall X \in G_0\), \(\forall Y \in G_1\), \({\hat{e}}(a \cdot X, b \cdot Y) = {\hat{e}}(X, Y)^{ab}\). For any elements \(X, Y, Z \in G_0, G_1\), \({\hat{e}}(XY, Z) = {\hat{e}}(X, Y) \cdot {\hat{e}}(X, Z)\). For any elements \(X, Y, Z \in G_0, G_1\), \({\hat{e}}(XY, Z) = {\hat{e}}(X, Z) \cdot {\hat{e}}(Y, Z)\). Nondegeneracy: For any two elements X and Y, there exists at least one element X such that \({\hat{e}}(X \times X) \ne 1\). Computability: For any elements \(\forall X \in G_0\), \(\forall Y \in G_1\), there exists at least one efficient way to compute \({\hat{e}}(X, Y) \in G_T\). Let \({\mathscr {S}}\) denote a set of user attributes, represented as \({\mathscr {S}} = \{att_{1}, att_{2}, \ldots , att_{n}\}\). Each attribute \(att_{i}\) in \({\mathscr {S}}\) has a corresponding set \({\mathscr {L}}_{i}\) of possible values, where \({\mathscr {L}}_{i} = \{x_{i,1}, x_{i,2}, x_{i,3}, \ldots , x_{i,n}\}\), with n being the total number of possible values for each attribute39. Now, consider \({\mathscr {S}}\) as an attribute set of a user, defined as \({\mathscr {S}} = \{{\mathscr {S}}_{1}, {\mathscr {S}}_{2}, {\mathscr {S}}_{3}, \ldots , {\mathscr {S}}_{n}\}\), where \({\mathscr {S}}_{i}\) corresponds to \({\mathscr {L}}_{i}\). An access structure33, denoted by \({\mathscr {W}}\), is defined as \({\mathscr {W}} = \{w_1, w_2, \ldots , w_n\}\), with each \(w_i\) belonging to \({\mathscr {L}}_{i}\). The access policy \({\mathscr {S}}\) satisfies \({\mathscr {W}}\) if and only if \({\mathscr {W}}\) evaluates to 1. Specifically, \({\mathscr {W}} = \lambda _i \in I_{w}\), where the attribute list \({\mathscr {S}}\) is defined as \(\{att_{1}, att_{2}, \ldots , att_{n}\}\), and \(I_{w}\) is given by \(I_{w} = \{i \,|\, 1 \le i \le n, {\mathscr {W}}_i \ne * \}\). We say that \({\mathscr {S}}\) satisfies \({\mathscr {W}}\), denoted by \({\mathscr {S}} \models {\mathscr {W}}\), if \({\mathscr {S}}\) matches \({\mathscr {W}}_{i}\) for all i ranging from 1 to n; otherwise, \({\mathscr {S}} \nvDash {\mathscr {W}}\). It important to note that \({\mathscr {S}} \models {\mathscr {W}}\) if the attribute set \({\mathscr {S}}\) meets the access structure \({\mathscr {W}}\), i.e., \({\mathscr {S}}_{i}\) equals \({\mathscr {W}}_{i}\) for all \(i = \{1, 2, 3, \ldots , n\}\). Conversely, when \({\mathscr {S}}\) does not satisfy \({\mathscr {W}}\), it is represented as \({\mathscr {S}} \nvDash {\mathscr {W}}\). In the proposed scheme, bilinear mapping is crucial for implementing attribute-based encryption (ABE), chosen for its unique properties that enhance secure and efficient access control for electronic medical records (EMRs). The specific reasons for using bilinear mappings over other hash functions include the following: Bilinear mappings facilitate the construction of ABE schemes, allowing for fine-grained access control. This means access to encrypted data can be regulated based on the user's attributes rather than their identity, enabling a more nuanced and secure access control mechanism. Additionally, bilinear mappings support the encryption and decryption processes for complex access policies efficiently, which is critical for medical records where different users (e.g., doctors, nurses, administrators) require varying levels of access based on their roles. The mathematical properties of bilinear maps are essential for ABE. For example, given groups \(G_1\) and \(G_2\) and a target group \(G_T\), a bilinear map \({\hat{e}}: G_1 \times G_2 \rightarrow G_T\) satisfies \({\hat{e}}(a \cdot X, b \cdot Y) = {\hat{e}}(X, Y)^{ab}\) for any elements \(a, b \in {\mathscr {Z}}^*_{\rho }\). This property is crucial for combining user attributes and access policies in a way that allows for efficient encryption and decryption. Furthermore, the nondegeneracy property ensures that there exists at least one pair \((X, Y) \in G_1 \times G_2\) such that \({\hat{e}}(X, Y) \ne 1\), providing meaningful cryptographic results essential for security. The computability property ensures that \({\hat{e}}(X, Y)\) can be computed efficiently for any \(X \in G_1\) and \(Y \in G_2\), which is important for practical implementation and performance. The security of ABE schemes built on bilinear mappings relies on well-established cryptographic hardness assumptions, such as the Bilinear Diffie-Hellman (BDH) assumption. These assumptions provide strong guarantees against various cryptographic attacks, ensuring the confidentiality and integrity of medical data. Bilinear mappings also allow for dynamic user management, enabling the addition and revocation of users without requiring re-encryption of existing data. This scalability is vital in a healthcare setting where user roles and permissions frequently change. Furthermore, the scheme can efficiently handle updates to access policies, making it adaptable to changing security requirements and user roles. In our proposed EHRChain model, four primary entities collaborate to ensure secure and efficient electronic health record management: the blockchain, the InterPlanetary File System (IPFS), the medical system (comprising doctors and smart healthcare devices), and the data user system. These components collectively represent the main entities and operational processes that underpin our framework (see Fig. 3). Our proposed EHRChain framework ensures secure data handling and scalable storage by integrating two core technologies: Attribute-Based Encryption (ABE) and the InterPlanetary File System (IPFS). ABE provides a fine-grained cryptographic access control mechanism that allows data owners to define access policies based on descriptive user attributes (e.g., role, department, or clearance level). Only users whose attributes satisfy the specified access policy can decrypt the associated data. This enables decentralized and flexible access control, aligning with the complex authorization requirements inherent in healthcare data sharing. For off-chain storage, EHRChain leverages IPFS, a peer-to-peer distributed file system that retrieves content using unique cryptographic hashes instead of traditional location-based addresses. Encrypted patient records are stored on IPFS, while their corresponding hash references are anchored on the blockchain. This design preserves data immutability and integrity, reduces on-chain storage overhead, and ensures efficient data retrieval. Together, ABE and IPFS form the foundational pillars of the EHRChain framework, facilitating privacy-preserving access control and scalable, decentralized storage for secure electronic health record management. The medical system comprises physicians and smart devices of the system. Doctors are responsible for encrypting and saving medical records. They utilize encryption and indexing algorithms to secure medical records and generate indexes for keywords. The encrypted records are then stored in IPFS, and their hash values, along with IPFS hash addresses, are recorded on the blockchain. System smart devices handle the registration of hospital personnel, assigning secret private keys associated with their attributes. Data users (DU) can be doctors, nurses, researchers, patients, etc. Each DU is assigned a key pair associated with their attributes by the system. To access medical records, a DU must request access from the hospital. After confirming their attributes meet system access policies, the DU receives a token to search for medical records. In our scheme, medical data is stored and searched using the Ethereum blockchain platform. Since blockchains are immutable, they are a reliable source for verifying data authenticity and integrity, due to their inability to be arbitrarily modified. IPFS enables permanent storage and sharing of various types of files. A unique hash value is assigned to each file based on its content. Furthermore, IPFS uses deduplication to effectively avoid redundant data storage. IPFS is used for medical records storage in our scheme. In our proposed framework (see Fig. 3), a key feature of our proposed EHRChain Model is the incorporation of a fine-grained access control scheme, which ensures that only authorized users can access specific medical records. This access control mechanism is tightly integrated with advanced data encryption techniques, safeguarding sensitive patient information from unauthorized access. We utilize robust key management protocols to securely distribute and manage encryption keys, adding an additional layer of security. Furthermore, EHRChain Model employs a hybrid storage solution where actual medical data is stored in a blockchain-friendly off-chain tool like IPFS (InterPlanetary File System). The hash generated from storing data on IPFS is then placed on the blockchain. This approach combines the immutable and transparent properties of blockchain with the scalable and efficient storage capabilities of IPFS, ensuring both security and efficiency in managing large volumes of medical data. Our proposed system model securely manages Electronic Health Record (EHR) using Ethereum blockchain and IPFS. Medical records are encrypted and stored on IPFS, with the hash address recorded on the blockchain. Authorized users can retrieve and decrypt the records, ensuring data integrity and confidentiality through cryptographic techniques. This case study demonstrates the functionality and security features of our proposed EHRChain Model in real-world applications. Step 1: The process begins with Dr. Bob documenting the necessary information of the patient, Alice. This information, denoted as \(P\), includes all relevant medical details. Step 2: Once the documentation is complete, Dr. Bob provides Alice with a private key, denoted as \(K_p\). Step 3: Alice's information \(P\) is then converted into a PDF document using a backend Node.js service. Step 4: The encrypted MongoDB symmetric key, denoted as \(E(K_{sym})\), is retrieved and decrypted using Dr. Bob's private key \(K_{bob}\). where \(D_{K_{bob}}\) represents the decryption function using Dr. Bob's private key. Step 5: The symmetric key \(K_{sym}\) is then used to encrypt the PDF file. where \(E_{K_{sym}}\) represents the encryption function using the symmetric key. Step 6: The encrypted PDF file \(E_{\text {PDF}}\) is stored on the InterPlanetary File System (IPFS). IPFS generates a Content Identifier (CID) for the stored file. Step 7: The generated CID is then stored in a block on the Ethereum blockchain network as part of a transaction. This transaction ensures that the CID and, therefore,fore, the linencrypted patient information is immutable and securely stored on blockchain. Step 8: To secure the storage of a medical record R, the physician (e.g. Dr. Bob) initiates the encryption process. The medical record R is encrypted and signed to produce CT and sigR respectively. This encrypted record \(CT^* = (CT, sigR)\) is stored in IPFS, which provides a hash address h corresponding to \(CT^*\). Furthermore, the hash value hR of the medical record and an encrypted hash address h0 are transmitted to the blockchain as part of a transaction, generating a block ID. Step 9: When Alice needs to access her medical records, she sends an access request with keywords to the hospital. Upon verification, the system's smart contract issues a search token \(STw = (ID, h, \gamma )\) to the authorized Data User (DU), such as Alice or a healthcare provider. The block ID in the search token allows the DU to read the hash value h from the corresponding block on the blockchain. By comparing h with the hash address stored on the blockchain,kchain,kchain,kchain, the DU verifies the integrity of the record. Once validated, the DU retrieves the encrypted medical record \(CT^*\) from IPFS using the hash address h and decrypts it using their private key to access the original medical information. The proposed EHRChain model ensures that Alice's patient information is securely documented, encrypted, and stored in a decentralized manner, leveraging the security and transparency of blockchain technology. The EHRChain framework is architected to support interoperability with widely recognized Electronic Health Record (EHR) standards, specifically Health Level Seven (HL7) and Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources (FHIR). This interoperability is achieved through standardized API interfaces and a data translation layer capable of mapping blockchain-anchored metadata and IPFS-stored encrypted patient records into FHIR-compliant JSON resources message formats. During the retrieval process, the framework queries the blockchain to obtain the corresponding IPFS content identifier, fetches the encrypted data, and converts them into a FHIR Patient or Observation resource for seamless integration with existing hospital information systems. In contrast, clinical data originating in HL7 format are processed by the ingestion module, which parses HL7 segments and maps them to the standardized schema of EHRChain prior to encryption and offline storage. By incorporating these mechanisms, EHRChain enables healthcare organizations to integrate the proposed blockchain-based system without disrupting existing EHR infrastructures, while maintaining data portability, regulatory compliance, and alignment with established interoperability frameworks. In our proposed framework (see Fig. 4), administrators and users interact through a decentralized application (DApp). Users, such as doctors and patients, are assigned roles defined by the system administrator, typically a hospital administrator. These roles govern granular access to the system's functionalities and data, ensuring secure and controlled operations. This case study illustrates the real-world application of our proposed EHRChain Model. In our scheme, we simulate the process of a patient Alice, who has been admitted to the hospital and then returns home. This detailed process demonstrates the practical application of our proposedEHRChain Model, ensuring secure, efficient, and controlled access to medical records in a real-world healthcare setting. EHRChain Model as an example, where administrators and users, including doctors and patients, interact through a decentralized application (DApp) where roles defined by the system administrator ensure secure and controlled access to medical data. This case study demonstrates the functionality and security features of our proposed EHRChain Model in real-world applications. The following are the detailed steps to complete the process: The administrator assigns roles, which include the Role Name and Account Address of the user, as shown in Fig. 4. Each user in the system has a role name and an account address. When a user requests an operation after roles have been assigned, the system checks the user's account address and role name from the Roles List. The functions can be performed if the validation is successful. The system then stores the information on the Ethereum Blockchain, which processes transactions for that information. Upon successful transaction confirmation, the system receives a success message from the blockchain layer, visible on the DApp browser, the interface of the proposed framework. Given a security parameter \(\lambda\), the system initially generates a set of public parameters \((G1, G2, GT, \lambda , e, p, g1, g2)\), where G1 and G2 denote two cyclic multiplicative groups with prime order p. The elements g1 and g2 serve as generators for G1 and G2 respectively, with \(g1 \in G1\) and \(g2 \in G2\). Additionally, \(e: G1 \times G2 \rightarrow GT\) represents the bilinear map. Furthermore, a collision-resistant hash function \(H: \{0, 1\}^{\lambda } \rightarrow {\mathbb {Z}}_p^*\) is established. Step 1: Registration and Diagnosis - Dr. Bob, a physician at the General Hospital, registers the patient Alice and generates a medical record R for him. The attributes for Alice are: \(S = \{name: Alice, age: 28, gender: male, identity: patient\}\), based on which a public-private key pair is generated. Subsequently, the system proceeds to randomly select parameters \(\alpha , \beta , \sigma \in {\mathbb {Z}}_p^*\). For each attribute i, where \(1 \le i \le m_g\), the system generates random values \(a_{i,t} \in {\mathbb {Z}}_p^*\), where \(m_i\) denotes the total number of possible values for attribute i. For instance, if \(i = 1\) corresponds to a doctor, \(i = 2\) to a nurse, and \(i = 3\) to an expert, then \(m_1\) represents the total count of doctors, and \(m_3\) represents the total count of experts. Finally, the system obtains the public key \(mpk = (G_P, e(g1, g2), H)\) and the master key msk. The equation outlines the setup process for a cryptographic system utilizing bilinear pairings and random parameter generation. It initializes public parameters including cyclic multiplicative groups G1 and G2 with prime order p, along with generators g1 and g2. A bilinear map e and a hash function H are established. Random parameters \(\alpha\), \(\beta\), and \(\sigma\) are chosen, along with attribute-specific random values \(a_{i,t}\). Finally, the system computes the public key mpk and the master key msk incorporating these parameters. The system has roles and account addresses for each user. A user's account address and role name are checked from the Roles List when they request an operation after roles have been assigned. If the validation succeeds, the functions can be performed. Meanwhile, the DU generates a search request utilizing its search private key and subsequently decrypts the medical records using its corresponding secret private key, which is linked to its set of attributes. Initially, the system computes \(Y = e(g1, g2)^{\alpha }\), \(B = g^{\beta }_1\), \(u_1 = g^{\sigma }_1\), and \(A_{i,t} = g^{a_{i,t}}\), where \(1 \le t \le m_i\) and \(1 \le i \le m_g\). Subsequently, it derives the public-private key pair (pko, sko) as follows: In Step 1, the system generates a public-private key pair for the Doctor. It computes \(Y = e(g1, g2)^{\alpha }\), \(B = g^{\beta }1\), \(u_1 = g^{\sigma }1\), and \(A{i,t} = g^{a{i,t}}\), where \(1 \le t \le m_i\) and \(1 \le i \le m_g\). The public-private key pair (pko, sko) is then derived as \(pko = (Y, B, u_1, A_{i,t}, 1 \le t \le m_i, 1 \le i \le m_g)\). and The equation represents the private key components for the Doctor, denoted as \(\text {sko}\). It includes parameters such as \(\alpha\), \(\beta\), \(\sigma\), and \(a_{i,t}\) for \(1 \le t \le m_i\) and \(1 \le i \le m_g\). The system randomly selects \(s \in {\mathbb {Z}}_p^*\) and computes \(D_1 = g^s_2\), \(u_2 = g^{\sigma }_2\), and \(D_2 = \prod _{t=1}^{m_i} u^{a_{i,t}}_2\). Additionally, it selects two random numbers \(x_i, \lambda _i \in {\mathbb {Z}}^*_p\), where \(1 \le i \le m_g\), and computes \(x = \sum _{i=1}^{m_g} x_i\), along with \(d_0 = g^{\alpha \cdot x \cdot \beta }\). For each attribute number i where \(1 \le i \le m_g\), when \(S_i = v_{i,t}\), it computes \(d_{i,1} = g^{x_i}_2 \cdot A_{i,t}^{\lambda _i}\), \(d_{i,2} = g^{\lambda _i}_2\), resulting in the private key pair (sku, skS): This equation represents the private key components for the Doctor, denoted as sko. It includes parameters such as \(\alpha\), \(\beta\), \(\sigma\), and \(a_{i,t}\) for \(1 \le t \le m_i\) and \(1 \le i \le m_g\). The doctor prepares a medical record R for the Data User (DU) after diagnosing the \(DU's\) condition and then uploads the medical record R onto the IPFS. Initially, to encrypt the medical record R, the doctor defines the ciphertext policy as \(W = [W_1, W_2,..., W_m]\). Random values \(r_i\) are selected for each attribute number i, and the ciphertext CT is computed based on the policy and associated attributes. Moreover, the doctor signs the ciphertext to ensure its authenticity. Next, the doctor uploads \(CT^* = (CT, sigR)\) via IPFS, which provides h for \(CT^*\). After storing medical records on the blockchain, the doctor logs the process. To obtain \(h_R = \text {SHA256}(h_R)\), he hashes the medical record R using the SHA256 hash function. With respect to h, he picks randomly \(\gamma \in {\mathbb {Z}}_p^*\) to calculate \(h_0 = h^\gamma\). After broadcasting a transaction and obtaining the block ID, he records the tuple \((h_R, h_0)\) on the blockchain. To facilitate searching, the Doctor must create indexes for the stored medical records. Initially, he extracts the keyword \(w = (w_1, w_2,..., w_m)\) from the medical record R. Subsequently, he chooses a random value \(y \in {\mathbb {Z}}_p^*\) and calculates \(I_1 = g^y \cdot H(w_1||w_2||\dots ||w_m)\) and \(I_2 = u_1 \cdot \prod _{i,t \in W_i} A_{i,t}^y\). Consequently, the Doctor obtains the index as \(I = (I_1, I_2)\). In this phase, the Data User (DU) intends to search for the keyword \(w_0 = (w_{01}, w_{02},..., w_{0m})\). Initially, the DU forwards a search request to the hospital. Upon identity verification of the DU by the system's smart device, a search token is provided. The DU forwards a request to the hospital containing the keyword \(w_0 = (w_{01}, w_{02},..., w_{0m})\). Subsequently, the DU randomly selects \(z \in {\mathbb {Z}}_p\) and computes \(T_1 = D_{z,H}(w_{01}||w_{02}||\dots ||w_{0m})\) and \(T_2 = D_z^2\). The request \((T_1, T_2)\) is then sent to the hospital. As soon as the Data User (DU) requests access, a test is performed by the smart device to determine whether the DU has authorization to access medical records containing \(w_0 = (w_{01}, w_{02},..., w_{0m})\). Initially, the system's smart device evaluates whether \(e(I_1, T_2)\) equals \(e(I_2, T_1)\). If \(e(I_1, T_2) = e(I_2, T_1)\), it signifies that the DU has permission to access the medical records containing the keywords \(w_0 = (w_{01}, w_{02},..., w_{0m})\). Afterward, the system's smart device sends \(ST_w = (ID, h, \gamma )\) to the DU, containing the block ID, the hash address h, and the random value \(\gamma\). On the basis of the block ID provided in the search token \(ST_w\), the DU retrieves the tuple \((h_R, h_0)\) from the blockchain. In the next step, he calculates \(h_{00} = h^\gamma\) alongside \(h_0\) to validate the accuracy of h. If \(h_{00} = h_0\), he retrieves medical records which contain the keyphrase \(w_0 = (w_{01}, w_{02},..., w_{0m})\) from the IPFS. Using the SHA256 hash function, the DU hashes the decrypted medical record \(R'\) and compares it to the blockchain hash value. Medical records R that \(h_{[0R]} = h_R\) can be considered original if \(h_{[0R]} = h_R\). The decryption operation in our proposed scheme is governed by a pairing-based computation, where the final result \(R'\) is derived by combining ciphertext components with user-specific decryption keys, as illustrated in Eq. (6). Once the Data User (DU) receives the ciphertext \(CT = (C_0, C_0, (C_{i,1}, C_{i,t,2})_{1 \le t \le m_i, 1 \le i \le m})\), he proceeds to decrypt it using his secure private key \(sk_S\). For each attribute number i, \(C'_{i,t,2} = C_{i,t,2}\) where \(S_i = (v_i, t_i)\). The decrypted medical record \(R'\) is computed as: As shown in Eq. (6), the decryption result \(R'\) is computed through bilinear pairings over the ciphertext components and corresponding secret keys. Smart contracts play a pivotal role in our DApp ecosystem, enabling essential operations and interactions. Our framework includes the following contracts: Patient Records: Facilitating CRUD operations on patient records, ensuring secure and tamper-proof management. Roles: Regulating user access and permissions within the DApp, maintaining data integrity and privacy. These contracts are instrumental in realizing the functionalities of our proposed framework, ensuring seamless interactions and robust data management. The primary smart contract in our system is responsible for executing CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations on patient records while also defining access roles. Secondly, the smart contract, known as Roles, comes from the OpenZeppel in library40, specifically the Asset library. This library offers tested and community-reviewed code, ensuring reliability. The Roles contract provides a granular role definition mechanism, making it an ideal choice for our system. In the following algorithm, we outline the operations and associated conditions of the Patient Records smart contract. The following algorithms outline the functioning of the smart contract dedicated to patient records. It comprises five functions: role definition, addition, viewing, updating, and deletion of records. These functions are accessible to administrators and other system users. The algorithm described in Algorithm 1 defines a function named AddPatientRecord, which is intended to be executed within a smart contract. This function is designed to facilitate the addition of new patient records to a healthcare system. It accepts as input the variables necessary to include data in a patient's record. Similar to the previous algorithm, this function begins by verifying the identity of the caller (msg.sender) to ensure that only authorized users, specifically doctors, can execute this function. If the caller is indeed a doctor, the function proceeds to insert the provided data into the specific patient's record. This typically involves creating a new entry in the database or appending the provided information to an existing patient record. However, if the caller is not identified as a doctor, the function terminates the session, preventing unauthorized access to the system. Overall, this algorithm provides a secure and controlled mechanism for adding new patient records within a blockchain-based healthcare system. Add data: smart contract function The algorithm described in Algorithm 2 defines a function named UpdatePatientRecord, which is intended to be executed within a smart contract. This function is designed to facilitate the updating of patient records in a secure and controlled manner.It given input to the values it needs to change within a patient's record. When invoked, the function first checks the identity of its caller (the msg. sender, so that only authorized users can use this function. It is checking, specifically, if the caller is a doctor. Assuming the caller is a doctor, the function then validates the supplied patient id and title against a stored patient. This step validates whether the provided doctor can update data of the specified patient. If the identifier and designation match what are currently stored in the patient record, the function goes ahead and updates the data. For example, this usually means updating the same fields in the patient record as you can provide input variables. If, on the other hand, the record is successfully changed, a call to the function returns a signal of success. If, in contrast, either the identifier or designation offered is inconsistent with the patient's record, the function returns a failure signal, indicating that the update had not been executed. Moreover, if the caller fails to identify himself or herself as a doctor, the function ends the session, denying them access to data such as patient records. This algorithm ensures up to date patient data without compromising patient confidentiality. Update data: smart contract function Algorithm 3 describes an algorithm that implements a function called AbortSession that can be run in a smart contract. It is designed for logging out from the health care system. This function does not require any input parameters like previous algorithms as it will end the ongoing session. What the function does is simply log you out or end your active session when you run it This is critical for maintaining security and privacy in the healthcare system, as users should be able to log out when they have completed their tasks or when they need to log out from the system. A simple in-session session termination within the smart contract would help improve the overall security and user experience of the healthcare application. Abort session: smart contract function The function implemented in Algorithm 4 is called DeletePatientRecord and it would be executed in a smart contract to delete patient records within the healthcare system. It takes the patient's ID, so it can go through the database and locate the exact record to delete. This checks whether the requestor of the request is authorized, i.e., in the case the requestor is a doctor. Once confirmed to be a doctor, the function still checks if the provided patient identifier matches the patient that needs to be deleted from the registry. If the identifiers match, the function goes ahead and deletes the patient record and returns a success message. However, if the identifiers do not match, it means that the provided identifier does not correspond to an existing record so the function returns a failure message. If the sender is not, the function stops immediately to avoid an unauthorized doctor access. It helps protect the integrity and privacy of patient data for authorized medical personnel, who may, if need be, remove patient records while ensuring the protection of sensitive healthcare data. Delete data: smart contract function This pivotal section delves into the performance evaluation of the proposed framework, aimed at mitigating the risks associated with the adoption of this innovative technology. Through rigorous testing and analysis, we assess the effectiveness, efficiency, and robustness of the framework in addressing key challenges and vulnerabilities inherent in the adoption of novel technologies like blockchain-based solutions. This crucial section focuses on the performance metrics of the suggested framework in minimizing the associated risks of implementing this sophisticated technology. Based on testing and assessment we investigate how well the framework quantities the challenges and vulnerabilities in the new technology, including efficiency, network/computation cost and robustness of solution relative to using a blockchain-based solution. The experiment setup is crucial in evaluating the functionality and efficiency of any framework or system. For our study, we prepared an experimental set-up specifically designed for performance testing in order to reproduce the findings correctly and without distortion. Experimental Setup: The experiment environment includes the hardware configuration, software tools, transaction dataset, evaluation metrics, and performance evaluation methods. All performance tests are done in a high-end desktop machine where we have more than sufficient processors, RAM, and so on. Hardware Configuration: Intel Core i7-6498DU CPU at 2.50GHz (base) and up to 2.60GHz (turbo boost) For RAM, the system sported 8.00 GB, or enough memory to run demanding computational processes. The Windows 10 operating system, specifically the 64-bit variant, was used for the desktop computer to test for compatibility and stability. To carry out the simulation, deployment, and evaluation of the proposed framework, development tools used in the experimental environment are important that systematically ensured the correct implementation of the simulation and experimental processes. We were able to leverage different tools which served for the different purposes and contributed to the overall process of performance testing. Using Remix – an online Integrated Development Environment (IDE) for writing, compiling, and deploying Ethereum smart contracts – made it possible to conduct programming in an easy to use interface. Simulation and development of the smart contracts that forms our suggested framework using Remix IDE With its web-based interface, it facilitated direct interaction with the Ethereum blockchain, allowing for on-spot testing and debugging of smart contracts. For the dApp, we use Metamask41, an Ethereum browser extension that is used as a digital wallet and as a bridge between web browsers and the Ethereum blockchain. In order to deploy and test the smart contracts on the Ethereum test network (Rinkby), we use Metamask. This made signing and broadcasting transactions easy and allowed the execution of smart contracts in the sandbox, simplified by its integration with different web browsers. The proposed framework was built around Solidity, the programming language for writing smart contracts on the Ethereum blockchain. Smart Contract Implementation - Solidity We used Solidity to implement the logic and functionality of smart contracts governing our proposed system. We utilized Solidity for our smart contracts and integrated them with Remix IDE to ensure the integrity of transactional items we were dealing with this way, adding the final layer of usability to our experimental environment. To simulate a realistic healthcare data environment, we generated a synthetic dataset comprising 5,000 electronic health record (EHR) transactions. Each transaction emulates common operations in a decentralized medical data management system, such as role assignment, patient record creation, update, retrieval, and deletion. The dataset was constructed to reflect typical healthcare system dynamics, incorporating various user roles (e.g., physicians, administrative staff, and data users) and record attributes such as patient identifiers, medical categories, timestamps, access privileges, and digital signatures. The simulated transactions were subjected to Attribute-Based Encryption (ABE) based on dynamic policy structures and were subsequently offloaded to IPFS for decentralized storage. Only the cryptographic hashes of these files were anchored to the Ethereum testnet, mimicking real-world system behavior while ensuring system efficiency and privacy compliance. This dataset model enabled us to assess how well the proposed EHRChain framework handles concurrent access, access control enforcement, and decentralized data storage under realistic operational conditions. The experimental evaluation was guided by a multi-dimensional set of performance criteria aimed at assessing the system's responsiveness, scalability, and resource efficiency under varied workloads. The core evaluation metrics include: Execution Time: This metric quantifies the temporal duration between the submission of a smart contract transaction and its successful confirmation on the blockchain. It reflects the computational and network delays associated with contract deployment and function invocation. Throughput (Transactions/sec): Defined as the average number of successfully processed transactions per unit time. This measures the system's capacity to handle concurrent operations, a critical factor in scalable healthcare infrastructure. Latency: Measured as the delay between a user-initiated request and the receipt of a system response. This includes smart contract call delays and consensus-related propagation times across the blockchain network. Gas Consumption and Transaction Fees: Each smart contract function incurs a gas cost, which is converted into Ether based on current gas prices. We calculated the financial cost of deploying and executing AssignRoles, AddRecord, ViewRecord, UpdateRecord, and DeleteRecord operations to analyze the cost-effectiveness of the proposed scheme. Storage Overhead: We evaluated the memory footprint introduced by storing encrypted EHRs on IPFS and maintaining their metadata on-chain. The analysis includes transaction payload sizes and their effect on blockchain bloat and off-chain storage scalability. The experimental setup leveraged Remix IDE42 for Solidity-based smart contract testing, Metamask for transaction signing41, and the Ethereum Rinkeby testnet for blockchain emulation. Apache JMeter was configured to simulate multi-user access patterns and concurrency levels ranging from 100 to 500 simultaneous users. Performance profiling was conducted in real time, enabling us to benchmark execution time variations, stress-test system throughput, and evaluate responsiveness under transactional load. This comprehensive performance evaluation demonstrates the viability of our framework for secure, scalable, and decentralized healthcare data management in practical deployment scenarios. The performance measurement method comprises analysis of transaction data and transaction information during the execution of smart contracts on the Ethereum blockchain. These transaction metrics are the transaction implementation time (tx1) and the transaction completion time (tx2). Transaction deployment time was the time taken to deploy a smart contract on the Ethereum blockchain, while Transaction Completion Time was the time needed for a transaction to complete and to be confirmed by the blockchain network. We perform simulations of real-world scenarios to evaluate how well our custom framework performs under the different quoting conditions. For this application, Apache JMeter was used as a performance testing tool to analyze the application's performance. To run these tests, we set up Apache JMeter to simulate multiple concurrent users using the system at the same time and record execution time, throughput, and latency as performance metrics. Through a rigorous analysis of the performance data and an in-depth evaluation of the framework, we obtained meaningful insights into its scalability, efficiency, and reliability. The average time taken to execute various transactions on the blockchain was measured. For instance, single-user functions such as “Assign Roles”, “Add Patient Records”, and “View Patient Records” exhibited execution times of approximately 18.29 s, 1 min 48 s, and 50 s respectively. These times increased proportionally with the number of concurrent users, demonstrating the scalability of our framework. The throughput of the system, represented in KB/sec, was assessed using Apache JMeter. Simulations were conducted with user loads ranging from 100 to 500. The results, depicted in Fig. 5, show the system's ability to handle varying loads efficiently. Throughput of the our proposed EHRChain framework. Latency, defined as the delay between sending a request and receiving a response, was evaluated using JMeter. Latency is measured in milliseconds. Average latency of our proposed EHRChain framework. The average latency, or the delay between sending a request and receiving a response, was also evaluated using JMeter. The highest recorded latency in our experiments was 14 milliseconds, as shown in Fig. 6. This metric is crucial for understanding the system's responsiveness under different conditions. There is a data payload field in every Ethereum transaction. The transaction includes a data payload, which is used to invoke the smart contract. The data payload is encoded in hexadecimal format and consists of bytes. In this section, we will discuss two Algorithm functions that we can use to gain a deeper understanding of data payload included in transactions. An optional data payload field is used when interacting with contract functions during a transaction. It consists of two parts: Function Selector Function Arguments Keccak-256 hash identifies a smart contract function by the first four bytes of the function selector. There are several types of static and dynamic elements in the function arguments, each of which is encoded differently in the payload. For an understanding of how data is generated, let us examine the payload from the Define Roles function in Algorithms. As a first step, we will separate the argument selector from the function selector. Function selectors are function signatures, such as the following: 0x 28e4a6af In this case, the function selector represents the hashed string of DefineRoles(address,uint256). In the data payload, the arguments are added after the function selector. This argument includes the new account address and the new role. Convert all the inputs into their hexadecimal representations and concatenate all this data. The payload is included in the transaction afterward. Lastly, by looking at the data payload we can get useful information about state changes in Ethereum transactions and smart contracts. When we can split the transaction payloads into their function selector and function arguments, we get a more in-depth look at how the smart contracts work. This emphasizes allows us to optimize the encoding and processing of these elements, further improving transaction efficiency. We use the types of the arguments in our functions to differentiate static and dynamic types, which allows us to use our channels more effectively as an encoding mechanism. This difference is an important one for reducing the amount of data sent in each payload and thus for enhancing the throughput of Ethereum transactions. We present a framework for estimating transaction sizes and costs around data payloads. Such an estimation is critically important to the understanding and management of the economic side of implementing blockchain-based solutions in healthcare. Assuming a gas rate of 21 Gwei and a consumption rate of 21,000, we can calculate the transaction fee as follows: This shows the fee calculation in both Ether and Gwei units. We provide a thorough analysis of the costs associated with Ethereum transactions, including gas consumption and transaction fees. Our framework includes strategies to optimize these costs, making it more economical for real-world applications. The framework incorporates advanced cryptographic techniques to enhance the security of medical records. By ensuring secure storage and transmission of sensitive data, our approach addresses significant security concerns in healthcare data management. The proposed framework is designed to be highly scalable and applicable to real-world scenarios. We validate its performance using real-world data and a comprehensive experimental setup, demonstrating its practicality and effectiveness in managing medical records. We introduce and evaluate specific performance metrics such as execution time, latency, and throughput using tools like Remix, Metamask, and the Rinkeby test network. These metrics provide a clear and quantifiable measure of the framework performance improvements. The storage and computational costs analysis about the different algorithms in Sharma et al. (2024)43, Sultana et al. (2024)21, and in our proposed study respectively. The storage costs of the three schemes are presented in Fig. 7. It appears that although our scheme incurs a higher storage cost in the KeyGen algorithm compared to schemes Sharma et al. (2024)43 and Sultana et al. (2024)21, the storage costs in Setup/Init, Trap/Index, and Search are significantly lower than those schemes. In this function, both static and dynamic types have a 32-byte size. A 64 byte function has a total byte size of 64 bytes. We can estimate the transaction sizes of our proposed framework by using the data payload. These transactions' sizes are shown in Table 3. Moreover, it is important to remember that the transaction size calculated in this section is based on the data payload and specifically calculated for each function. In contrast, the transaction size has been calculated from a block size perspective and is a generalized calculation. In addition, the proposed framework allows us to calculate the cost associated with various transactions. There are certain units associated with Ethereum, such as wei and gwei, which are used for calculating transaction fees. This article also discusses the formula for calculating Ethereum transactions fees. For a transaction, the transaction fee is calculated by multiplying gas consumed by gas price. The performance of the proposed EHRChain framework was rigorously evaluated with respect to two primary operational metrics: scalability, quantified as Transactions Per Second (TPS), and latency, defined as the mean transaction finality time from request submission to blockchain confirmation. Comparative analysis was conducted against two representative blockchain-based EHR management models: (i) Ramesh et al. (2023)31, which employs a fully on-chain architecture with Practical Byzantine Fault Tolerance (PBFT), and (ii) Sharma et al. (2024)43, which adopts a blockchain–cloud hybrid approach leveraging conventional symmetric encryption for off-chain data handling. The performance of the proposed EHRChain framework was evaluated against existing approaches by Ramesh et al. (2023) and Sharma et al. (2024). As illustrated in Fig. 8, EHRChain consistently achieves higher throughput in terms of transactions per second while maintaining significantly lower latency under varying concurrent user loads. This demonstrates the scalability and efficiency of our framework compared to prior solutions. Performance comparison between EHRChain, Ramesh et al. (2023), and Sharma et al. (2024). (a) Scalability in TPS. (b) Average transaction latency in milliseconds. EHRChain was deployed with a hybrid PoS+PBFT consensus protocol and integrated with the InterPlanetary File System (IPFS) for off-chain storage. Performance benchmarking was conducted using the Hyperledger Caliper framework, with simulated transaction loads of 100, 300, and 500 concurrent requests. To ensure methodological rigor, identical transaction payloads and system configurations were applied across all comparative models. EHRChain demonstrated superior throughput characteristics under increasing workloads. At 500 concurrent transactions, the framework sustained a throughput of 248 TPS, corresponding to a 7.4% degradation relative to the 100-user baseline (268 TPS). By contrast, Sharma et al.43 model achieved 198 TPS (12.2% degradation), while Ramesh et al.31 fully on-chain system recorded 143 TPS (21.6% degradation). These results indicate that the decoupling of bulk EHR data from on-chain storage significantly mitigates consensus bottlenecks, thereby enhancing scalability. EHRChain also outperformed the baseline systems in transaction finality time. At peak load, the average latency was 412 ms, representing a 47.2% reduction relative to Ramesh et al. (781 ms) and a 26.8% reduction compared to Sharma et al.43 (563 ms). The latency gains are attributable to reduced block payload sizes, parallelized IPFS retrieval, and an optimized consensus configuration tuned for healthcare transaction patterns. The empirical results confirm that EHRChain maintains high throughput and low latency under concurrent load conditions typical of real-world healthcare environments. The hybrid consensus protocol, combined with off-chain IPFS storage, delivers a balanced performance profile that addresses both the scalability limitations of fully on-chain systems and the latency constraints of cloud-based hybrids. Consequently, the framework is well-positioned for deployment in scenarios demanding real-time, privacy-preserving, and high-volume medical data exchange. During the search process, if the attributes set \(S = \{S_1, S_2, \ldots , S_m\}\) satisfies the access policy \(W = \{W_1, W_2, \ldots , W_m\}\), where \(W_i \in L_i\), then, If \(w_0 = w\), and \(e(I_1, T_2) = e(I_2, T_1)\), this means that the DU has the privilege to access the medical record containing the keywords \(w_0 = \{w_{01}, w_{02}, \ldots , w_{0m}\}\). During the decryption process, if the attributes set \(S = \{S_1, S_2, \ldots , S_m\}\) satisfies the access policy \(W = \{W_1, W_2, \ldots , W_m\}\), where \(W_i \in L_i\), then, A challenge policy is proclaimed by the adversary at the beginning of the game, with \(W_0\) and \(W_1\). The notation we use is \(W_b = \{W_{b,1}, W_{b,2}, \ldots , W_{b,m}\}\) these are expressed as \(b \in \{0, 1\}\). There is no proof in the literature that an adversary is capable of winning the original game G. Thus, we prove that our scheme is secure by exploiting the indistinguishability of \(G, G_0, \ldots , G_{l-1}, G_l\). Changing the ciphertext component of game G first results in a new game \(G_0\). In-game \(G_0\), if the adversary does not have \(sk_S\) generated from S such that \(S \models W_0 \wedge S \models W_1\), the adversary will choose a random number in GT as the ciphertext component \(C_0\), while the rest will remain unchanged. Aside from the b, the adversary generates component \(C_0\) which is the same as in-game G based on their attribute S. In this case, \(G = G_0\). Assuming asymmetric DBDH, the difference in adversary advantage A between games G and \(G_0\) is negligible with the security parameter k. Given the asymmetric challenge tuple \(h(g_1, g_2, g_{Z11}, g_{Z12}, g_{Z22}, g_{Z23}, Z)\), where \(Z = e(g_1, g_2)^{Z1Z2Z3}\) is equivalent to a random number with the same probability. \(hfill\square\) Init: When the adversary A promises to simulate B two challenge ciphertext policies \(W_0\) and \(W_1\), then B flips a random coin b, in which \(b \in \{0, 1\}\). If \(b = 1\), then \(Z = e(g_1, g_2)^{z_1z_2z_3}\), else Z is a variable. Setup: The simulator B starts by getting the system public parameter using the security parameter \(\lambda\). A public key \(pk_0\) is then generated for adversary A using the KeyGen algorithm. Using the simulator B first sets \(Y = e(g_1, g_2)^{z_1z_2}\), \(B = g^{z_1^2}\), \(u_1 = g^{z_3}\), this implies \(\alpha = z_1z_2\), \(\beta = z_2\), \(\sigma = z_3\). The simulator generates \(A_{i,t}\) for each attribute number ij, if \(1 \le i \le m\), \(1 \le j \le m\), it generates \(A_{i,t}\), if \(v_{i,t} \in W_{b,i}\), the simulator B sets \(A_{i,t} = g^{\alpha _{i,t}}\). Otherwise, the simulator B sets \(A_{i,t} = g^{z_{11}^{\alpha _{i,t}}}\), where \(z_{11} \in {\mathbb {Z}}_p^*\) varies. Last but not least, the simulator B publishes public parameters Y, B, \(u_1\), \(A_{i,t}\). The security proof our proposedEHRChain model involves a thorough evaluation to ensure its robustness against potential vulnerabilities. EHRChain utilized the open-source tool Oyente, which applies symbolic execution techniques to scrutinize smart contracts by executing functions step by step. Oyente operates exclusively with the Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM) and does not require access to high-level representations like Solidity or Serpent. Our focus was on bolstering the security of a blockchain-based healthcare system designed for managing Electronic Health Records (EHRs) securely. Step 1. In frame number 1, Alice is a healthcare provider who interacts with a critical smart contract in our blockchain healthcare system that handles the access control to patient records. The goal was to employ strong security practices to protect patient data privacy, correctness, and availability. Step 2. we chose Oyente, as it has the ability to symbolically execute and systematically explore paths in Ethereum smart contracts. Insolvency for example, If contract malicious user invokes it – This would allow for detailed examination of possible entry points for attacks like reentrancy, integer overflow or underflow, out-of-gas errors, unexpected state changes and cross-function state changes, etc. Step 3. The step-by-step simulation performed by Oyente explores different execution paths and input variations to find vulnerabilities. During this audit, it found a critical reentrancy vulnerability in the access control function of our smart contract. An attacker named Bob could use recursive calls to adjust privileges and attack the program using this vulnerability. Step 4. After discovering the reentrancy vulnerability, our development team applied the “Checks-Effects-Interactions” pattern in the code of the smart contract. This guarantees that all critical functions begin with condition validation (Checks), state modification based upon validated conditions (Examples), and secure external interaction handling (Interactions). This added a layer of protection only an internal call to the guard would let the process continue, and when reentrancy was detected it would revert the entire transaction. Step 5. After implementing the mitigation strategies, we re-executed Oyente to check if our mitigation strategies were effective. Later reports showed a marked decrease in flagged vulnerabilities, a sign that the effort was leading to an enhanced security posture and greater resilience to the common threats faced by blockchain projects. Step 6. This work illustrates how the use of Oyente for tool-based assessment allowed to discover serious vulnerabilities and in addition to address their effective mitigation in our blockchain-based healthcare system. This perspective safeguards patient data saved onboard development while also navigating developing security hazards. The security analysis, illustrated in Fig. 9, indicates that the majority of the outputs in the analysis report are “False,” which means that the smart contract in our proposed model is resilient against many well-known vulnerabilities. This underscores the robustness and security of the proposed model. However, the analysis revealed vulnerabilities in two areas: integer overflows and integer underflows. Both of these vulnerabilities are manageable and temporary. An integer overflow occurs when the number of integers required to execute a function exceeds the specified limit, while an underflow occurs when the number of integers falls below the threshold necessary for the function to run properly. Security proof of our proposed EHRChain system model. A comparative evaluation of blockchain-based methodologies focusing on access control, scalability, and contributions to the field is presented in Table 4. This table contrasts previous studies with the proposed EHRChain model, demonstrating how our approach uniquely integrates blockchain, fine-grained access control, and scalability features to address gaps identified in the existing literature. To assess computational costs among the three schemes, we define time-consuming operation symbols, including the bilinear pairing operation (\(OP\)) and exponentiation operations (\(OE\)). From Fig. 7, the evident that our scheme exhibits superior efficiency in the Init, Index, and Search algorithms, except for the KeyGen algorithm. Furthermore, considering the different result verification mechanisms, we analyzed the computational costs only in our scheme and the Sharma et al. (2024) scheme29. Based on the above information, we can infer that our scheme facilitates access control without introducing additional storage and computational overhead. However, further verification of this fact is necessary. In healthcare systems, access control mechanisms must strike a balance between preserving patient privacy and ensuring rapid data availability, particularly during mission-critical situations such as medical emergencies, natural disasters, or rapid administrative changes in user roles. Traditional Attribute-Based Encryption (ABE) offers a robust fine-grained access control paradigm, yet it exhibits inherent limitations in handling exceptional access requirements and dynamically revoking privileges. The proposed EHRChain framework addresses these challenges by incorporating advanced extensions to the baseline ABE model, specifically to support: Emergency access provisioning – granting controlled, short-term access to patient data under verified urgent conditions. Revocation of access rights – removing user privileges promptly when their authorization status changes or security risks are detected. Under conventional ABE, decryption is rigidly policy-bound: if a user attribute set does not match the embedded access policy, access is unequivocally denied. While this ensures strict adherence to predefined policies, it can hinder timely interventions in acute medical emergencies, where treating physicians or authorized responders may require immediate access to life-critical patient data. Our proposed EHRChain introduces a context-aware override mechanism facilitated through a dedicated EmergencyAccess attribute. This attribute is issued by a designated authority, such as a hospital administrator, security officer, or a smart contract-governed trust entity, following the verification of emergency conditions. The mechanism is designed with the following safeguards: Time-bound validity: Emergency access credentials are embedded with cryptographically enforced expiration timestamps, automatically revoking privileges after the predefined duration (e.g., 30 minutes to 2 hours), thereby preventing prolonged or unmonitored access. Scope-limited access: Emergency attributes are strictly bound to relevant datasets or patient records associated with the ongoing critical event, minimizing unnecessary data exposure. Immutable on-chain auditability: Each emergency access request, approval, and usage instance is permanently recorded in the blockchain ledger, enabling post-incident forensic analysis, regulatory compliance verification, and deterrence against misuse. Multi-factor verification: Prior to attribute issuance, an additional verification layer–such as biometric confirmation or secondary authorization from another administrator–can be enforced to strengthen trust in the emergency request. This design ensures that emergency access is operationally efficient while preserving the overarching privacy and compliance guarantees of the system. Access revocation presents a well-documented challenge in traditional ABE systems, as the attribute–ciphertext relationship is static and re-encryption typically requires system-wide re-keying. In healthcare settings, where staff assignments, operational roles, and trust statuses can change frequently, this limitation can result in security risks if not addressed effectively. To overcome this, EHRChain incorporates a dual-layered revocation strategy: Expiration-based key validity: All attribute keys are issued with cryptographically embedded expiration timestamps. Users must periodically request renewed keys, which are only issued if their current role and authorization remain valid, thereby automatically removing access for inactive or reassigned personnel. Proxy-assisted re-encryption: Upon the occurrence of a revocation event, such as role reassignment, employment termination, or detected key compromise, a trusted proxy entity (e.g., a hospital blockchain node) re-encrypts affected ciphertexts using updated access policies. This ensures that previously valid credentials cannot be used to decrypt data post-revocation, without necessitating full re-keying of the entire user base. The integration of proxy-assisted re-encryption provides a scalable and resource-efficient mechanism for dynamic policy enforcement, essential for large-scale healthcare deployments. The practical realization of the proposed EHRChain framework is grounded in healthcare-specific regulatory, operational, and compliance imperatives, ensuring its suitability for deployment in real-world clinical environments. The framework adopts a permissioned blockchain architecture in conjunction with a consortium-governed IPFS network, enabling authenticated participation within a secure and controlled trust domain. This design not only mitigates the risk of unauthorized node inclusion but also inherently satisfies the stringent privacy, security, and accountability requirements associated with the management of sensitive electronic health information. From a regulatory perspective, EHRChain is architected to align with internationally recognized compliance regimes, including the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) in the United States, the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) in the European Union, and established interoperability specifications such as HL7 and Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources (FHIR). Conformance with these standards is achieved through the integration of Attribute-Based Encryption (ABE) for fine-grained, policy-driven access control; immutable blockchain-anchored transaction logs for verifiable auditability; and the off-chain storage of encrypted EHR data within IPFS to prevent unauthorized data disclosure. Collectively, these mechanisms safeguard the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of medical records while supporting comprehensive compliance auditing. Operational viability is reinforced through the modular and standards-compliant architecture of the framework, which facilitates seamless integration with existing Hospital Information Systems (HIS) and Regional Health Information Exchanges (HIE) without necessitating disruptive infrastructure replacement. This integration model reduces deployment complexity and cost while preserving continuity of care and existing clinical workflows. Furthermore, as demonstrated in “Scalability and latency analysis of the EHRChain framework”, empirical performance evaluations confirm that EHRChain sustains high throughput and low latency transaction processing under varying concurrent user loads, validating its scalability and robustness for large-scale healthcare ecosystems. In addition, governance policies embedded within the permissioned network enforce role-based participation, transaction validation rules, and jurisdiction-specific compliance constraints. These measures ensure that deployment across multiple healthcare organizations can be tailored to local regulatory requirements while maintaining interoperability across the broader ecosystem. As such, EHRChain not only offers a technically robust solution but also demonstrates regulatory and operational readiness for secure, scalable, and privacy-preserving electronic health record management in diverse healthcare settings. This research presents a comprehensive evaluation of a novel framework aimed at enhancing the security and efficiency of blockchain-based medical record management systems. Utilizing Ethereum smart contracts and detailed transaction payload analysis, the study explores various aspects of performance, including execution time, latency, and throughput. Our findings indicate that the proposed framework offers substantial improvements over existing methods. Through rigorous testing using tools like Remix, Metamask, and the Rinkeby test network, we have shown that the framework can handle complex transactions with improved speed and reduced delays. The detailed analysis of transaction payloads and their encoding demonstrates the robustness and scalability of our approach, ensuring that the system can support a high volume of transactions while maintaining security and integrity. Furthermore, the study provides insights into the costs associated with Ethereum transactions, offering a clear understanding of the economic implications of deploying such a framework in real-world scenarios. The research introduces a robust framework to enhance the security and efficiency of blockchain-based medical record management systems, showcasing significant performance improvements in execution time, latency, and throughput. However, the conclusion lacks explicit mention of the study's limitations. Future work will address this by focusing on implementing attribute revocation functions for better access control, integrating smart contracts to enhance data functionality, exploring advanced cryptographic techniques for improved security, investigating interoperability with other blockchain platforms, optimizing gas consumption for cost-effectiveness, developing dynamic access control algorithms, and conducting real-world implementation and testing in healthcare environments to validate the practical utility of the framework and identify potential challenges. Future studies could also delve into optimizing the gas consumption and transaction fees associated with Ethereum, making the framework more cost-effective for large-scale deployments. Another potential direction is the development of more sophisticated algorithms for dynamic access control, ensuring that only authorized users can access specific medical records based on evolving policies and user roles. Finally, real-world implementation and testing in healthcare environments will be crucial to validate the framework's practical utility and identify any additional challenges that may arise in a production setting. These future efforts will help in refining the framework, making it a viable solution for secure and efficient medical record management on the blockchain. Wall Street's next crypto play may be IPO-ready crypto firms, not altcoins
Source: TradingView    Published: 2025-10-03 11:37:48

Wall Street's growing interest in late-stage cryptocurrency firms could disrupt the traditional boom-and-bust cycle of digital assets, according to new research. Crypto financial services firm Matrixport said Friday that more than $200 billion worth of crypto companies are preparing initial public offerings (IPOs), which may raise between $30 billion and $45 billion in new capital. Matrixport said investor focus is rotating away from early-stage bets toward scalable, IPO-ready companies positioned for public markets. Continued selling by Bitcoin (BTC) miners and early adopters has “nearly neutralized ETF and treasury inflows, reducing volatility and dampening Bitcoin's appeal to risk-seeking investors,” Matrixport said in a Friday X post. “Wall Street, however, has every incentive to extend the bull market, with up to $226 billion in crypto IPOs waiting in the pipeline that could raise $30 - $45 billion in new capital.” The report comes as multiple high-profile crypto firms are preparing IPO plans, including crypto exchange Kraken, which reportedly recently secured $500 million in funding at a $15 billion valuation, according to unidentified sources cited by Fortune on Sept. 25. The news came less than a week after crypto custodian BitGo filed to list its common stock on the New York Stock Exchange under a US IPO filed on Sept. 19. The Palo Alto-based company reported about $90.3 billion in assets under custody and a user base of 4,600 entities and 1.1 million users. ETFs signal “paper-backed altseason” for select altcoins Matrixport's report supports previous insights from industry watchers, who predicted that the 2025 crypto market cycle will not feature an altcoin season akin to previous years, but will only see select altcoins with institutional backing or outstanding exchange-traded fund (ETF) filings outperform the rest of the market. Still, some analysts argue that onchain dynamics point to the beginnings of an altcoin season. “While many investors remain myopically focused on Bitcoin, ETH is quietly outperforming in the background” as Bitcoin dominance drops toward “year lows,” according to Nic Puckrin, crypto analyst and co-founder of crypto educational resource The Coin Bureau. “Historically, these have been the signals of a reversal into altcoins,” though he stressed the trend has been selective so far. Other analysts are pointing to the pipeline of ETF filings awaiting approval as the next potential catalyst for the incoming altcoin season. “Entering paper-backed altseason,” said Ki Young Ju, the founder and CEO of blockchain analytics platform CryptoQuant, in a Monday X post. This comes as the crypto industry awaits the Securities and Exchange Commission's (SEC) decision on outstanding crypto ETF filings related to at least five tokens, which were submitted during October. Canary Capital's Litecoin LTCUSD ETF's deadline was set for Oct. 2, but the SEC kept silent on the ETF filing. It is unclear whether the lack of response is due to the ongoing US government shutdown or new generic listing standards, which would render the 19b-4 deadline irrelevant. Multiple Solana (SOL) ETF filings from Grayscale, VanEck, 21Shares and Bitwise are facing a decision by Oct. 10. Later in the month, XRP (XRP) ETF filings from Grayscale, WisdomTree, Bitwise and CoinShares are awaiting feedback between Oct. 19 and 24. Lastly, Grayscale's Dogecoin (DOGE) ETF and Cardano (ADA) ETF are both expected to receive a final decision before the end of October. Select market data provided by ICE Data Services. Select reference data provided by FactSet. Copyright © 2025 FactSet Research Systems Inc.Copyright © 2025, American Bankers Association. CUSIP Database provided by FactSet Research Systems Inc. All rights reserved. SEC fillings and other documents provided by Quartr.© 2025 TradingView, Inc.

HYPER ICO Slams $20.4M Raised as Presale Skyrockets $1.2M in 72 Hours
Source: 99Bitcoins    Published: 2025-10-03 11:28:21

By Sam Cooling Last Updated: October 3, 2025 Fact checked By 99Bitcoins Editorial Team History could be in the making for Bitcoin (BTC) Layer-2s as Bitcoin Hyper (HYPER), the fastest in development, has already secured $20.4M in presale funding. Fresh off surpassing the $19M milestone earlier in the week, Bitcoin Hyper quickly attracted another $1.2M in just three days. Multiple whale purchases have again been key drivers, pushing the project's funding to its latest total. With smart money already moving in, this scale of capital shows Bitcoin Hyper is shaping up to deliver what many expect to be the ultimate convergence of Solana-grade efficiency with Bitcoin's security. At the current pace, the presale could potentially reach the $21M mark before the end of the week. Currently, investors have the opportunity to join the round at $0.013035 per HYPER, but only for the next 33 hours, before the price increases in the next stage. The time-tested reputation of “Uptober” isn't letting bulls down, with Bitcoin pushing back to the $120,000 mark – a level not seen since mid-August, when it notched its all-time high at $124,128. BTC has now logged two consecutive days in the green and appears poised for a third, fueling broader optimism across the market. That same wave of bullishness is spilling into Bitcoin Hyper, where early investors view the project not only as a breakthrough Layer-2 but also as a potential demand driver for BTC itself. Bitcoin Hyper is building an ecosystem that combines the strongest features of blockchain: Solana's transaction speed and cost efficiency, paired with Bitcoin's decentralization and security. https://twitter.com/BTC_Hyper2/status/1971583436457750549 Under the hood, it relies on the Solana Virtual Machine (SVM) to provide developers with parallelized execution and familiar Rust-based tools, making it possible to build high-performance dApps without sacrificing Bitcoin's settlement guarantees. If Bitcoin can already reach $124,000 purely as a store of value, the introduction of Bitcoin Hyper – with BTC flowing into its canonical bridge and wrapped BTC circulating freely within its ecosystem – could unlock a far greater trajectory for the asset. The week isn't even over, and Bitcoin Hyper has already drawn massive capital inflows to its presale, led by aggressive whale accumulation. On Monday, one whale made three separate purchases totaling 24.6M HYPER tokens worth $327,000. By Thursday, others had joined in. Two more whales scooped up a combined 25.65M HYPER – one accumulating 10.81M tokens for $140,000, while the other collected 14.84M tokens for $193,000. Source: https://etherscan.io/tx/0xdaf9d22a4b06ec0680e29a80448d9c1498b47bd33dc47bd120b59ee8367436e4 Such moves are often seen as savvy investments – whales or even institutions deploying significant capital into assets they believe have long-term potential. With access to deeper data, sharper analysis, and larger resources, these players are often ahead of the curve, which is why retail investors frequently view their activity as a valuable signal. Smart money piling into Bitcoin Hyper shows additional conviction that the project could become a true driver of new Bitcoin demand and a leading force in the Layer-2 landscape. DISCOVER: Next 1000X Crypto: 10+ Crypto Tokens That Can Hit 1000x in 2025 Beyond gaining exposure to Bitcoin's fastest Layer-2 and the demand it could drive for BTC itself, investors are also looking at HYPER as their chance to get in early on what could feel like redemption for missing Bitcoin's early days. BTC remains one of the most remarkable investments in history – from around $0.05 in 2010 to $120,000 today, a gain of nearly 240,000,000% that changed countless fortunes. Yet not everyone had the opportunity to ride that ship, which is why many now look for projects that could replicate even a fraction of that trajectory. Source: TradingView HYPER represents both Bitcoin's roots and its evolution. Wrapped BTC will serve as the medium of exchange within applications, but it is HYPER that powers the system – facilitating payments for transactions, staking, and governance. Without HYPER, the entire Solana-plus-Bitcoin model would stall, making it indispensable to the network's function and growth. That's why many see HYPER as more than just another token. It's the key to unlocking a new demand avenue for Bitcoin, and one of the most respected crypto outlets, 99Bitcoins, has already projected it as a potential 100x token. DISCOVER: 20+ Next Crypto to Explode in 2025 The smart money moves already tell the story, and more could flow in over the coming days as the presale heats up, with $20 million expected to be reached before the end of the week. To be part of Bitcoin's biggest Layer-2, investors can purchase HYPER directly through the Bitcoin Hyper website using SOL, ETH, USDT, USDC, BNB, or even a credit card. You can also grow your HYPER holdings immediately by staking through the project's native protocol, which currently offers a 59% APY. Bitcoin Hyper recommends Best Wallet – one of the best crypto wallets in the market – where HYPER is already listed under its lauded new project screening tool Upcoming Tokens, which makes it easy to buy, track, and claim once live. Join the Bitcoin Hyper community on Telegram and X for the latest scoop about the project. EXPLORE: Is Standard Chartered Set to Pump Polygon?
